0.text: For most of our history, human technology consisted of our brains, fire, and sharp sticks.

6.text: While fire and sharp sticks became power plants and nuclear weapons,

10.text: the biggest upgrade has happened to our brains.

13.text: Since the 1960's, the power of our brain machines has kept growing exponentially,

17.text: allowing computers to get smaller and more powerful at the same time.

21.text: But this process is about to meet its physical limits.

25.text: Computer parts are approaching the size of an atom.

28.text: To understand why this is a problem, we have to clear up some basics.

39.text: A computer is made up of very simple components

44.text: Representing data, the means of processing it, and control mechanisms.

49.text: Computer chips contain modules, which contain logic gates, which contain transistors.

54.text: A transistor is the simplest form of a data processor in computers,

58.text: basically a switch that can either block, or open the way for information coming through.

63.text: This information is made up of bits

66.text: which can be set to either 0 or 1.

68.text: Combinations of several bits are used to represent more complex information.

73.text: Transistors are combined to create logic gates which still do very simple stuff.

78.text: For example, an AND Gate sends an output of 1 if all of its inputs are 1, and a output of 0 otherwise.

85.text: Combinations of logic gates finally form meaningful modules, say, for adding two numbers.

91.text: Once you can add, you can also multiply,

93.text: and once you can multiply, you can basically do anything.

97.text: Since all basic operations are literally simpler than first grade math,

101.text: you can imagine a computer as a group of 7-year-olds answering really basic math questions.

106.text: A large enough bunch of them could compute anything

111.text: However, with parts getting tinier and tinier,

113.text: quantum physics are making things tricky.

116.text: In a nutshell, a transistor is just an electric switch.

119.text: Electricity is electrons moving from one place to another.

123.text: So, a switch is a passage that can block electrons from moving in one direction.

128.text: Today, a typical scale for transistors is 14 nanometers,

132.text: which is about 8 times less than the HIV virus' diameter,

135.text: and 500 times smaller than a red blood cell.

138.text: As transistors are shrinking to the size of only a few atoms,

142.text: electrons may just transfer themselves to the other side of a blocked passage

145.text: via a process called Quantum Tunneling.

148.text: In the quantum realm, physics works quite differently from the predictable ways we're used to,

153.text: and traditional computers just stop making sense.

156.text: We are approaching a real physical barrier for our technological progress.

162.text: scientists are trying to use these unusual quantum properties to their advantage

169.text: In normal computers, bits are the smallest unit of information.

173.text: Quantum computers use qubits which can also be set to one of two values.

178.text: A qubit can be any two level quantum system,

180.text: such as a spin and a magnetic field, or a single photon.

184.text: 0 and 1 are this system's possible states,

187.text: like the photons horizontal or vertical polarization.

190.text: In the quantum world, the qubit doesn't have to be just one of those,

194.text: it can be in any proportions of both states at once.

199.text: But as soon as you test its value, say, by sending the photon through a filter,

204.text: it has to decide to be either vertically or horizontally polarized.

209.text: So as long as it's unobserved,

211.text: the qubit is in a superposition of probabilities for 0 and 1, and you can't predit which it'll be.

217.text: But the instant you measure it,

219.text: it collapses into one of the definite states.

224.text: Four classical bits can be in one of two to the power of four different configurations at a time.

230.text: That's 16 possible combinations, out of which you can use just one.

234.text: Four qubits in superposition, however, can be in all of those 16 combinations at once.

240.text: This number grows exponentially with each extra qubit.

244.text: Twenty of them can already store a million values in parallel.

248.text: A really weird and unintuitive property qubits can have is Entanglement,

252.text: a close connection that makes each of the qubits react to a change in the other's state instantaneously,

258.text: no matter how far they are apart.

260.text: This means when measuring just one entangled qubit, you can directly deduce properties of it's partners

267.text: Qubit Manipulation is a mind bender as well.

271.text: A normal logic gate gets a simple set of inputs and produces one definite output.

276.text: A quantum gate manipulates an input of superpositions, rotates probabilities,

281.text: and produces another superposition as its output.

284.text: So a quantum computer sets up some qubits, applies quantum gates to entangle them and manipulate probabilities,

291.text: then finally measures the outcome, collapsing superpositions to an actual sequence of 0s and 1s.

297.text: What this means is that you get the entire lot of calculations that are possible with your setup, all done at the same time.

304.text: Ultimately, you can only measure one of the results and it'll only probably be the one you want,

309.text: so you may have to double check and try again.

312.text: But by cleverly exploiting superposition and entanglement,

315.text: this can be exponentially more efficient than would ever be possible on a normal computer.

320.text: So, while quantum computers will not probably not replace our home computers,

325.text: in some areas, they are vastly superior.

328.text: One of them is database searching.

330.text: To find something in a database, a normal computer may have to test every single one of its entries.

335.text: Quantum computers algorithms need only the square root of that time,

339.text: which for large databases, is a huge difference

342.text: The most famous use of quantum computers is ruining IT security.

346.text: Right now, your browsing, email, and banking data is being kept secure by an encryption system

352.text: in which you give everyone a public key to encode messages only you can decode.

356.text: The problem is that this public key can actually be used to calculate your secret private key.

362.text: Luckily, doing the necessary math on any normal computer would literally take years of trial and error.

367.text: But a quantum computer with exponential speed-up could do it in a breeze.

372.text: Another really exciting new use is simulations.

375.text: Simulations of the quantum world are very intense on resources,

379.text: and even for bigger structures, such as molecules, they often lack accuracy.

384.text: So why not simulate quantum physics with actual quantum physics?

388.text: Quantum simulations could provide new insights on proteins that might revolutionize medicine.

394.text: Right now, we don't know if quantum computers will be just a specallized tool,

398.text: or a big revolution for humanity.

400.text: We have no idea where the limits of technology are,

403.text: and there's only one way to find out.
